utterance: Aladdin's palace wasn't as splendid as that, I know, even if he could have had the roc's egg. I should like to see it, though. Oh, dear, I wish fairy stories were true!
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Why, they are, child! Didn't you know that?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: No. I mean really and truly true! just like going to school, and to meeting, and your dinner, and your hew shoes.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Well, they are as true as all those things, if you only go to them, instead of sitting there and wishing.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Go to them, Chimney-Elf! why, how can any- body go to a story?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Of course you can go to them. Fairy stories and all that sort of thing live in the moon, and you've only to go to the moon to find them.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Fairy stories live in the moon?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Yes, my dear. But that's a very bad way you have of echoing a person's words; very rude, indeed; and I've told you so before.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: I know it, but-how do they live there?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: How! How do you live in Yankee-land?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Why, I-just live here.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: And they just live there; and when the moon shines they come sliding down the beams, and get into people's heads, and they write them down and call them their own, and that's the way fairy stories, and poetry, and all that, comes into the world.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Oh, but, Chimney-Elf, if I should go to the moon, could I see all these beautiful stories going on, just as people do all round here?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Yes.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: What! see Cinderella, and Little Red Riding- Hood, and Beauty and the Beast, and Jack the Giant- Killer, and all the rest of them?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Yes, yes, yes!
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: And Robinson Crusoe, and the Arabian Nights, and Jack and the Beanstalk, and-
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Every thing and every body, I tell you! Every story that ever was written is true somewhere or some- how; men and women are not bright enough to make anything up; all they can do is to tell over what they have seen and heard. Well, some things are true of the world just about you, and those you call real; and some other things you don't see are just as true, and those you call unreal; and all the unreal true stories come from the moon, and are real stories there.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Oh, Chimney-Elf, I wish I could go to the moon!
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Well, why not?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Why not go to the moon?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Yes.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Because I can't get there.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Oh, yes, you can, if I tell you how.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Can! Oh, do tell me how, dear, good Chimney- Elf.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: There, none of that. I don't like coaxing, and I am no dearer or gooder than if I didn't know how to go to the moon.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: But-will you tell me how?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Perhaps I will. You can only go once a month, and, as it happens, to-night is the very night for this month.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Why only once a month?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Because the moonglade only comes right once a month.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Oh, can we go up the moonglade?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Yes, we can go up the moonglade, if you will behave like a sensible child, and not be frightened. All that you have to do is to come down to the beach a few minutes before sunset, for you know the full moon rises just as the sun sets, get into the dory, and paddle a little way out from the shore. I will be there, and do all the rest. You must not tell a mortal creature where you are going. I don't want everybody rushing to the moon, and making it common.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Nobody will care what I do. Father is going to marry the Widow Merriam, and he goes to see her every night as soon as we have done tea; and my sister Susy is so busy getting the house ready for father's wedding and her own, that she don't remember me when she don't see me; and Mrs. Marsh, who helps her, only says:
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Massy me! if that child was mine, I bet she wouldn't be wasting her time and eyesight over books that way!' And Susy laughs and says:
speaker: Mrs. Marsh

utterance: It's all the fun she wants, poor little Rhoda!' So I go on reading; and father and brother Ben always bring me a book when they go to the city with market- ing.
speaker: Susy

utterance: There, that will do, you chatterbox. Do you suppose I have lived in this chimney ever since it was a chimney, for something over a hundred years before you were born, without knowing all about the family. And isn't it just because you are lonesome and neglected, and given to books and dreams, and nonsense generally, that I have taken notice of you? Try to tell me what goes on under this roof-do!
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: I'll be in the dory at sunset, Chimney-Elf!
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: I'm going out in the dory a little while
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Go along, but don't stay out after dark
speaker: Susy

utterance: Well, my dear, do you intend to go on dreaming all night in that mooning fashion? Although, why I should call it moon- ing I don't know, since you have your back to the moon. Turn round, and see where we are!
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Why, where did you come from, Chimney-Elf?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Never mind me, child. Turn round, and look!
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Can that be the moon, the same old moon that shines into the kitchen windows, and that Bruno barks at?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: NOW, then!
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: What shall we do with the dory?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Oh, it will take care of itself, and wait for us as long as we like. The dory knows.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Oh, how I like to be here!
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Wait until you see some of the people; then you may not like it so well. Suppose we should meet the wolf that ate up Red Riding-Hood, or some of the giants that Jack didn't kill: they all live here.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: I don't believe they will hurt me.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Oh, Chimney-Elf! I forgot to ask you. Do the people out of the stories keep on doing those same stories over and over, or do they do new ones all the time?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Well, it is very much in the moon as it is in the world. Some people like to do the same things over and over, and think that because they always did them, they are the best things possible to do, and that all the rest of the world ought to do so too: others like a change. But we will call upon the Man in the Moon, who can tell you everything about the people here, even better than I can, though I came from here in the first place.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: You did?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Yes. But here you are-that's the house.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Why, here's the Chimney-Elf, and Rhoda along with him. How d'ye do, Rhoda?
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: Very well, I thank you, sir.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Why, it's because I so often send you fancies and dreams by the moonbeams. I never went down myself but once, and that was all a mistake. It was when Diana got lost, you know, Chimney-Elf.
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: Yes. Tell Rhoda about that.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Well, I will. You see, Rhoda, my daughter Diana-by the way, I have several more girls, Cynthia, Luna, Phoebe, and one or two more whose names I have forgotten; but Diana was the favorite. She was always rather a tom- boy, liking to play with bow and arrows, and run races and romp with the dogs, better than to read, or sew, or put the house in order. At last she took to going down to the earth almost every night; and the people who saw her were so pleased with her, that they built temples for her to live in, and gave her flowers and jewels, and flattered and praised her until the girl's head was fairly turned. She played all sorts of wild tricks upon her admirers. Why, there was a young man named Actæon,. who offended her in some way, and she turned him into a stag, and set his own dogs to chase him; they chased him right out of the world, and up here to the moon : they have not caught him yet, that I have heard of. After that, Diana fell in love with a young man called Endymion, and declared she would marry him. When I heard that, I thought it was high time to go and bring her home. So I told one of the moonbeams to inquire where she was last heard of.
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: She's gone to Norridge, of course.
speaker: a saucy boy

utterance: So I slipped down on the next moonglade, and went all about asking my way to Norridge, getting laughed at for my pains; for it seems that in those days "Gone to Norridge" meant the same that gone to Jericho, or Noddler's Island, or Dixie, or any such expression means now: there was no place in the world really called Norridge. So I came home again, and sent my dog down next, and a half-a- dozen moonbeams with him. The dog was to find Diana, and the moonbeams to tell her that if she would come home, and bring Endymion, I would set them up at house-keeping, and all should be forgiven. So she came; and they live just over the hill near the Cheese Mine.
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: But there is a place called Norridge pretty near where I live, when I am at home; only they spell it Norwich.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Oh, yes; after my inquiries had made the name so popular, a good many towns were called Norridge. Only, you see, I came down too soon, before they were built.
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: Oh, dear! oh, my! o---h!
speaker: the Man from the South

utterance: What's the matter? Burnt it again?
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: Yes; oh, dear me! oh, my! oh, dear!
speaker: the Man from the South

utterance: That's rather curious, Rhoda, isn't it? This Man from the South, you see, has a trick of blowing hot and blowing cold in the same breath; and so long as he remembers to blow cold on his porridge it does very well, for he con- siders ice quite a luxury; but sometimes he forgets and blows hot, and that heats the frozen porridge so suddenly that he burns his own mouth. Silly enough, isn't it? But it's the way he always did do, and I suppose it is the way he always will do.
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: Which way, which way? Oh, my eyes, my eyes!
speaker: the wondrous wise man

utterance: Straight forward as you are now; one, two, three- and away you go—run!
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: Eyes! who says I haven't eyes! I fancy I can see as far into a millstone as most men, at any rate.
speaker: the wondrous wise man

utterance: I've read about him, and the Man in the South, and —and you too, sir, all in Mother Goose: that is just what the Chimney-Elf said!
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: What-that the stories people down there call fairy- stories, and Mother Goose, in fact-stories, are all true up here? Yes, that is correct, quite correct.
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: All fancies, and a great many ideas, come from the moon. The moonbeams go when people are asleep, and put them into their heads, and when they wake up they write them down, and call them their own.
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: Everybody don't write them down.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Everybody don't get them! The moonbeams know whom to carry them to. Sometimes, however, they make a mistake, and stuff too many fancies into the brain of somebody who can't write them, or tell them, and so get rid of them, and he keeps them stored away until they turn his brains upside- down. Then the other people, who never were troubled with fancies or ideas, call these poor stuffed people luna- tics-thinking that my daughter Luna has made them what they are, I suppose; and they shut them up in luna- tic asylums. Lunatics, indeed! If they only had gone to a writing-school when they were young, they would have been called geniuses, and nothing could have been too good for them. Sometimes the moonbeams pour in ideas faster than the brain can arrange or put them together, even if the person does write them down, and then they make queer work enough of it for a while, but finally join the lunatics. But the Cltimney-Elf is grow- ing cross, and you and he had better go on: see what you can, while you stay! I'd take her to the Cheese Mine, Chimney-Elf.
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: Well, if you ever stop talking, I mean to.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Right over Old Woman's Hill.
speaker: the Man in the Moon

utterance: Oh! oh! oh! oh! I've burnt my mouth-oh, my mouth!
speaker: the Man from the South

utterance: What's the matter?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: That noise? Oh, it's only the Old Woman that lives in the Shoe putting her babies to bed. They cry that way just for fun, you know: she only pretends to whip them; she's as good-natured as she can be. Here's where she lives, just at the foot of the hill.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: They eat right out of the kettle. Poor thing, she has so many children she don't know what to do; and as for baking bread enough for such a family, it is quite out of the question, so they never have any. Run up and look into the shoe, if you like.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: There, you're all done for now, and I will go and help toss Sister Broomster.
speaker: the Old Woman that lives in the Shoe

utterance: You see, my family is as troublesome as ever, Mr. Chimney-Elf; but they are all quiet at last, and I am going out for a little recreation.
speaker: the Old Woman that lives in the Shoe

utterance: Going to toss Mother Broomster, eh? Nice recrea- tion that, for those who like it. Well, Rhoda, we may as well see the show. Come along.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Come, sister, come along; we are late already!
speaker: the Old Woman that lives in the Shoe

utterance: Yes, yes, I'm coming, coming right along.
speaker: a cracked voice
addressee: the Old Woman that lives in the Shoe

utterance: How d'ye do, Rhoda?
speaker: another old woman

utterance: I'm the Old Woman that lives under the Hill; and if I don't move, I suppose I shall live there still. Come along, Sister Shoester!
speaker: the Old Woman that lives under the Hill
addressee: the Old Woman that lives in the Shoe

utterance: Oh, how d'ye do, Mother What-do-you-think? What do you find to agree best with your delicate stomach, now-a-days?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Is that you, Chimney-Elf? Well, I do declare! And Rhoda too! How d'ye do, Rhoda? I'm proper glad to see you. First time you ever came to the moon, isn't it? What were you asking, Chimney-Elf-what do 1 find to live on? Well, I hardly know; but I expect victuals and drink are the chief of my diet, just as they are of most folkses; and—oh, my! I do declare, if there isn't Sister Banbury on her White Horse, and all her jewelry. I never did!
speaker: Mother What-do-you-think

utterance: There, that's enough, What-d'ye-think.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: That's Banbury Cross, and Mother Banbury lives just beyond it, with her three lit- tle boys: the one holding the horse is the Baker's Man, who spends most of his time patting the cakes, and mark- ing them with T; one of the others goes round with a basket to sell hot cross-buns, when his mother happens to make any; and the other is apprenticed to the black- smith, who shoes the old horse, and shoes the old mare, and lets the little colt go bare. But it won't do to let it go bare much longer, or he'll have the Society for the Pre- vention of Cruelty to Animals after him. Hark!
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: It isn't sleigh-bells, for there isn't any snow.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Sleigh-bells, pho! It's Mother Banbury. Look at her now!
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Mother Banbury is fond of dress, and so is Margery Daw. See her?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Oh, here's Sister Broomster. Now let's toss her!
speaker: the Old Woman that lives in the Shoe

utterance: How d'ye do, Mother Broomster? Haven't you got the sky clean yet? You have been at it ever since I can remember.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Well, no, Chimney-Elf, there are a few cobwebs left-those white things, don't you see?
speaker: Mother Broomster

utterance: Why, those are clouds!
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Little girl, did you ever try to teach your grandmother to suck eggs?
speaker: the Old Woman that lives in the Shoe

utterance: No, ma'am.
speaker: Rhoda
addressee: the Old Woman that lives in the Shoe

utterance: Then, don't you ever do it, my dear. As for those being clouds, isn't it likely that I should know what they are, better than you, when I have been all my life sweeping them down for cobwebs, and you never went near them?
speaker: Mother Broomster

utterance: Now then.
speaker: the Old Woman that lives in the Shoe

utterance: Now, then!
speaker: all the old women

utterance: She's going seventy times as high as the mooK. It's lucky she don't have to start from the earth, isn't it? But, listen!
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Upward beat, downward beat, inward beat, outward beat. Sing!
speaker: Mother Banbury

utterance: Sing!
speaker: the four old women, and Margery Daw

utterance:
Old woman, old woman, oh, whither so high!
To sweep the cobwebs from the sky,
And I'll be back again by-and-by.
speaker: the four old women, and Margery Daw

utterance: Why, they sing the whole of it! I should think they would wait, and let Mother Broomster answer for herself.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Nonsense, child, you don't understand scien- tific music. The sense has nothing to do with it—the sound is everything.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: But I don't think it sounds as well as if the right one made the answer.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: That's because your musical education has been neglected, my poor little Rhoda. But come, we needn't stay here any longer: they'll keep on singing that until she comes down to-morrow morning. We'll get on toward the Cheese Mine, and on the way look in at the dancing-hall.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: I suppose you've heard of the Cow that jumped over the Moon? People gen- erally suppose that she lived on the earth, and jumped up over the moon and down again; but such people could never have noticed a cow's habits very particu- larly they never jump high, but, like the one we just saw, they often jump about, over the moon's or the earth's surface. This cow is coming out as a ballet- dancer as soon as Barry O'Lynn can find time to make her a belt with a fringe to it.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: See here, Chimney-Elf. Who are those people knocking at the door of that pretty little cottage
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Why, that's Tadpole Frog and the Rat-don't you know? Wait, and I'll make Tad tell you himself. Hallo, Tad! what are you doing there?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Oh, I thought it was ma, you know. I-I'm going to make a little call, Mr. Chimney-Elf, I and the Rat.
speaker: Tadpole Frog

utterance: A little call, eh! Why, who lives here?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Miss Mouse, I-I believe.
speaker: Tadpole Frog

utterance: Miss Mouse! She's a spinster, isn't she?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Ye-yes, sir.
speaker: Tadpole Frog

utterance: And you're going to woo her for your bride,' as the song says?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Ye-yes, sir.
speaker: Tadpole Frog

utterance: Well, I suppose your mother is willing, Tad, eh?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Mother she-well-I-I can't say, Mr. Chimney. Elf.
speaker: Tadpole Frog

utterance: They'll take them off before they go in. They won't handle poor lit- tle mousie with mittens, I can tell you; but then she shouldn't have opened the door. That was the trouble.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Here we are over the hill, at the Cheese Mine.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Oh, is this the Cheese Mine?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Yes; you know that the moon is made of green cheese-sage-cheese, some wise people call it, because sage means wise, and it is only sage people who know much about the moon, especially the inside of it. Well, the most of the cheese does not lie upon the surface, you know, but has to be dug for, like gold and silver upon the earth. This is the principal mine. Would you like to go down?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Very much.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: And that is the true story of Richard Whittington.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Oh-Whittington and his Cat! I am so sorry I did not hear that. Do please tell it to me again, Chimney-Elf! I couldn't listen, coming down the shaft.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Why, I was saying that after Whittington left London with his cat in his arms, and stopped under the tree to hear Bow-bells ring out 'Turn again, Whitting- ton, Lord Mayor of London,' he went to sea; but instead of landing in a savage country, as the story says, he got shipwrecked, and floated about the ocean on a raft, he and his cat together, until, while he was fast asleep one night, his raft got into a moonglade, and when Richard awoke he was in the moon. He did not know it, however, and nobody took the pains to tell him. I doubt if he ever found it out. While wandering about, soon after his arrival, he came upon the Cheese Mine. Being rather hungry, he asked if he might go down and dig his luncheon for himself. The miners told him that nobody could go into the mine, on account of the rats and mice who had taken possession of it, and who would eat a man as quick as they would a candle, if he came in their way.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Pooh! if that is all, I will send Bow-bells down first, and he will soon clear the way.' Bow-bells, you understand, was the name of the cat, given him in honor of the handsome promise that had recalled Whittington to London. But when the miners understood him, they all cried out, No, no! that won't do; for what will the Marquis of Carabas say?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: That was the name of Puss in Boots.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Yes. And, as the miners explained to Whittington, Puss in Boots, after he had grown rich and got his title, became very proud and lazy; the more good fortune that befel him, the more he wanted-like some other people. Among the rest of his privileges, he had obtained that of keeping all the rats and mice in the Cheese Mine for his own pleasure and use; so that when he fancied to go hunting, either alone or with his friends, he might always know where to find plenty of game. A very nice arrangement for the Marquis of Carabas, you see; but not so nice for the poor people whose cheese the rats and mice lived upon while waiting for the Marquis to come and kill them. Well, the miners explained all this to Whitting- ton, and to Bow-bells, who stood listening, with his back very much arched, and his upper lip quivering away from his sharp white teeth. When they had heard the whole story, Whittington laughed aloud, and stooping to smooth Bow-bells' rounded back, he said:
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Why, that's all nonsense. Puss in Boots has no right to keep rats and mice to eat up other people's cheese; and what's more, he shan't do it. Shall he, Bow-bells ?
speaker: Richard Whittington

utterance: Bow-bells gave a miau of defiance that sent every mouse in the mine to his hole for shelter. Then he went down among them-and such havoc as he made! All the galleries were choked with the bodies of the slain, and the whole neighboring country was overrun with the fugitives who managed to escape. Not a rat, not a mouse was left to show his tail.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Bow-bells had finished the battle, and was just sit- ting down to lick his paws clean, when a message was brought that the Marquis of Carabas desired the pres- ence of the cat and the man who had invaded his domain, and meddled with the game sacred to his use.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Whittington, after consulting Bow-bells, replied that if the Marquis of Carabas wished to see either cat or man, he must come to them, as they were too busy to go to him.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Bow-bells beat, as might have been expected, for the Mar- quis of Carabas had almost for- gotten how to fight, and had be- come very fat and lazy since he came to his fortune, having no need to hunt, except for amusement. Bow-bells beat, and the Marquis was very glad to come to terms. He agreed henceforth to allow him to kill as many rats and mice as he wanted; to live in the Cheese Mine as long as he chose; in fact, to do exactly as he pleased, so long as he would allow the Marquis of Carabas to creep away home, with ragged ears, and great patches torn out of his sleek velvet coat.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Bow-bells, having always been poor, and obliged to earn his own living, did not know how to spend his time in indolence, but just kept on with his work until the Cheese Mine was entirely cleared of mice, both living and dead; for the former he drove away, and the latter he devoured.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: For this service, the Man in the Moon presented him with a vote of thanks, and a silver tea-set. To the first, Bow-bells replied, Miau! and as for the second, he suggested that a handsome sum of money given to his master, and a free passage for both of them back to earth, would be much more to the purpose. The Man in the Moon held a council, and concluded to do as he was requested, although quite sure that his own plan was the best. So they gave Whittington a bag- ful of gold, and sent him back upon the next moon- glade to the earth-the moonbean who conducted him taking the precaution to steal the memory of his visit out of his head while he was asleep, lest he should make the secrets of the moon common and vulgar. The cat remembered it all well enough, but along with the memory of his visit, Whittington lost the power of understanding Bow-bells' language, and even the knowl- edge that he had a language; so that, although almost any cat you meet could tell you the story of Bow-bells' duel with the Marquis of Carabas, there is not a man, woman, or child on earth who ever heard it, or who knows the true origin of Whittington's fortune. But come, Rhoda, this is not seeing the Cheese Mine.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: And is all the cheese got in this way?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Oh, no. This is the principal mine; but then there is a great deal of cheese found just below the surface, and that the inhabitants can pick up for themselves. In some places, every man has his cheese-cellar in his own yard, and when he wants a piece, just steps down and' cuts it out of the wall. Now, there's the Little Boy that lived by himself--I dare say you have heard of him; he mines his own cheese, and we will step up and see him. This way.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Hallo, Little Boy! Going to mend that wheel-barrow again?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Why, yes, But the old thing never will stay mended since that first time.
speaker: Little Boy

utterance: What time? Tell Rhoda about it.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Why, it happened this way, Rhoda. When I was young, I was quite small, so that they used to call me Little Boy; and in fact, they do so now. But after father and mother died, I lived here by myself, and kept house the best way I knew how. I've got a cheese-cellar out here, and I made my own bread and such things. When I had finished a meal, I'd just put the bread and cheese on a shelf in the kitchen; after a while, though, the rats and the mice that Bow-bells sent wandering all over the moon, found me out, and I had no peace day nor night from them. At last, one day, as I was laying about me with a broomstick, trying to kill or drive away a few of my tormentors, Baron Bluebeard, who was riding by, stopped to see what was the mat- ter; for I suppose I made a good deal of noise. When I had explained the case to him, he smiled horribly, and said:
speaker: Little Boy

utterance: Get a wife, Little Boy, that's the way to do. Get a wife!
speaker: Baron Bluebeard

utterance: Then he rode on, and I sat down to think of his advice. It seemed to me pretty good; and the next time I went to Moonopolis, I asked Lydia Locket to marry me. She agreed, in case she found her pocket before the wedding. While we were still talking, Kitty Fisher stepped in to say that she had found it. The only trouble then was, that the Lockets lived in the very middle of the city, and the lanes were so narrow that no coach could get into them, although some of the streets were ridiculously wide. The only way seemed to be for me to bring my wife home in a wheel-barrow; for of course the Lockets, who are very smart people, would not let a daughter of theirs walk to her wedding.
speaker: Little Boy

utterance: Lydia agreed to the wheel-barrow, and we were married all right; but on the way home, the unlucky wheel-barrow broke down, and spilt Lydia into the mud, all dressed in her beautiful pocket, trimmed with green lace, and the rest of her wedding finery.

Now I consider myself settled for life; I am disgusted with the world, and never desire to return to it. But, Rhoda, that carpet is a very convenient piece of furniture, is it not? The way this wolf supports himself is by coming to the brook, and waiting beside the spring until he sees a sheep drinking lower down. Then he rushes out, says the sheep has muddied the water he was about to drink. and, no matter what the sheep says, he falls upon him and kills him. Sometimes he strips off the skin, washes it clean in the brook, wraps it around his own gray hide, and cheats simple folks into believing him to be a sheep. This is what he has done with Red Riding-Hood this time; and because he wore a sheep's skin, the silly child never suspected that he was the same old wolf from whom she has been rescued so often, and warned against so many times. You do not know of what you are talking, child. But look, what comes

utterance:
I think they are more gentlemen like the one we

speaker: lady

By my faith, that

And so it does. But what riders does he

speaker: Sir Galahad

Sir Galahad, right glad am I to see you, and you

you
I am safe, and that the noble lord of whom you

utterance:

utterance:

speaker: Sir Galahad

Sir Guy du Fontaine. They quarrelled about a

speaker: Lady Isolde

utterance:
And where is Sir Lancelot now, and who is this

speaker: Sir Galahad

utterance:
Here comes our lord the king: had not the Lady

speaker: Sir Percivale

utterance:
To him and to you together; for though the king

speaker: Lady Isolde

utterance:
Do not fear, my little maid, but that your friend

utterance:
Here comes

Come then, little one, thou shalt be my fair lady

utterance:
Thank you, sir; if the

speaker: Rhoda
Sir Percivale

Yes, sir: the gentleman you call Sir Percivale asked

Sir Percivale chose thee for his lady at the feast

Yes, ma'am; and he is going to wear a rose as a sign

speaker: Rhoda

"I had intended to give Sir Percivale to Ygonde the

speaker: the queen

utterance:
Nay then, dame, I think he hath chosen well

speaker: the king

utterance:
"Is the flower named from thee, or art thou named

speaker: Sir Percivale

utterance:
"Oh, if you please, don't talk that way to me. Sir

here everything is different, and I don't quite know—"
speaker: Rhoda

utterance:
"Did you come from that strange dim world that
they tell us we all used to live in? Sometimes I
remember like a dream that I was not always here," said Sir Percivale thoughtfully. "But after all, this
is the real life, and that was only a vision; so let it pass,
dear little Rhoda, and we will take our places at the
table. It is fairly laid, is it not?"
speaker: Sir Percivale

utterance:
"There is feasting in our good king's hall to-day,
and right merry are the noble knights, as well they may
be, living in Arthur's presence."
speaker: husbandmen

utterance: "The noble knight Sir Lancelot du Lac!"
speaker: the chamberlain

utterance:
"I have, first of all, my Lord Arthur, to crave pardon
for appearing thus before your majesty ; but mine errand
must be my excuse, for I bring you first a false and
forsworn knight, whom but this morning I conquered
fairly, and who with my dagger at his throat yielded
himself my prisoner, passing his word, as knight and
gentleman, to practise nothing farther against me or a
certain lady whom I had the good fortune to rescue
from his hands. After that, losing my horse, I was mak-
ing my way through the wood on foot, when I again
encountered mine enemy, who seeing me dismounted
and partially disarmed, set upon me with murderous
intent; and but that God and my Lady helped me, he had
slain me. But in the end I conquered once again, so
wounding him that I think he will be content to rest
awhile from his evil deeds. Then mounting my cap-
tive's horse, and leading him, pinioned as you see him,
I rode softly on until at a turn of the road I came upon
this giant carrying the dwarf. He was driving before
him a herd of beeves, of which he had robbed a luckless
hind, taking him captive also. Perceiving me, the
herdsman ran forward in spite of the giant's threats,
and kneeling, set forth his hard case, begging for help
and redress."
speaker: Sir Lancelot du Lac

utterance:
"The story told, I ordered the giant to give up his
ill-gotten booty and release his prisoner, the which
demands he refused with insolence, and swinging his
iron mace about his head, dared me to attack him. This
was not to be endured, and making suddenly in, I struck
him so shrewd a blow upon the sword-arm that the mace
fell crashing to the ground, and well-nigh the arm with
it. A few more blows brought my poor giant to his
knees and to reason; whereupon I bound up his arm,
tied him to the other end of the rope already securing
my first captive, and so brought him forward, thinking
that my Lord Arthur might accept the giant, and my
liege lady the queen might fancy the dwarf, as humble.
offerings from their unworthy knight Lancelot."
speaker: Sir Lancelot du Lac

utterance:
"Many thanks, fair knight and brother; and we accept
the gift right joyously," replied the king graciously.
"And what of your other captive, Sir Guy du Fon-
taine?"
speaker: the king

utterance:
"He also is at Your Grace's disposal, for I can make
no terms, even those of honorable enmity, with a das-
tard and a liar."
speaker: Sir Lancelot du Lac

utterance:
"Nor can we count such among the knighthood of
our realm," replied the king gravely. "We have already
heard of Sir Guy du Fontaine's misdeeds from the Lady
Isolde of Escourt. We now ordain that he be for to-night
kept in close ward, and that to-morrow, before the jousts
begin, he shall stand upon a scaffold in face of all the
court; and that then and there his spurs shall be hacked
from his heels by the common headsman, the crest shall
be shorn from his helmet, and the bearings upon his
shield shall be effaced and blotted from our roll of armo-
rial and knightly bearings. So let it be."
speaker: the king

utterance:
"Heaven be praised that he was never of the Round
Table," said Sir Percivale, looking sternly after the dis-
honored knight.
speaker: Sir Percivale

utterance:
"I suppose the king knew that none of those he
chose for the Round Table could do anything mean or
wicked," said Rhoda.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance:
"Think you so, little maid ?" asked her companion,
smiling brightly. "However that may have been, full
well do all of us feel, that being chosen, we no longer
belong to the world or to ourselves, but to our lord the
king, and through him to his Lord, who is the Lord of
heaven and earth."
speaker: Sir Percivale

utterance:
"And now, if my lord the king excuses me, I will go
and lay off this stained and cumbrous armor, and don
garments better suited to ladies' presence and royal
feasting."
speaker: Sir Lancelot du Lac

utterance:
"Go, but return anon, fair sir," replied the king;

"And prithee, Sir Lancelot, take the giant and the
dwarf away with you. They spoil our merriment with
their ugliness."
speaker: the queen

utterance:
"I had hoped that your majesty would accept the
dwarf as an offering from the humblest of your knights," replied Sir Lancelot, bowing lowly, and suffering his eyes
to rest reproachfully upon the queen's haughty face.
speaker: Sir Lancelot du Lac

utterance:
"Nay, I care not for such grewsome playthings;
give him rather to the little lady of the wood who came

her good graces."
speaker: the queen

utterance:
"Your majesty shall be obeyed," replied Sir Lancelot,
again bowing almost to the ground; but as he raised his
head, those who watched him saw the angry flush which
not all his pride could control. Then, signing to the

sitting, and said:
"Pardon me, fair lady, that I have not before offered
you my respectful thanks for your kind company in the
wood, and your gentle patience when I was forced to
leave you for a time. Will you kindly accept from me
this dwarf, who, little though he be, is so quick of wit
and limb that he cannot fail to become a valuable
servant, and may at least serve to remind you sometimes
of Lancelot."
speaker: Sir Lancelot du Lac

utterance:
"Very prettily spoken; but in fact all the world
knows that Sir Lancelot du Lac is always ready with
pretty speeches for every child or woman who will
listen to him," said the queen, laughing scornfully.
Guinevere the Fair could not endure that those she
liked should offer even courtesy to any other than her-
self; and being queen and almost undisputed in what-
ever she said or did, she had never learned to hide or
restrain her jealous temper. But Lancelot never looked
toward her or seemed to listen to her biting words, as
he stood bending over Rhoda's chair, waiting for the
answer which she did not know how to make.
speaker: the queen

utterance:
"I must see the king! I must speak to our good

speaker: Hop-o'-my-thumb's mother

utterance:
"Let her ap-
proach. What would you of the king, dame?"

utterance:
"Justice, Lord Arthur. That dwarf is my child,

ing where to look for child or kine. Edmund our

mother claims him, and holds out her arms to him, and

speaker: Hop-o'-my-thumb's mother

utterance:
"Come hither, manikin. Is the good woman's

utterance:
"Yes, my Lord King, and a right good mother too," replied Hop-o'-my-thumb, kneeling beside the king's

speaker: Hop-o'-my-thumb

utterance:
"And you would like to return home with her,

speaker: King Arthur

utterance:
"Yes, your majesty. In my father's cabin I call

speaker: Hop-o'-my-thumb

utterance:
"You speak shrewdly as well as drolly, manikin," replied the king, smiling. "And if Sir Lancelot du Lac

utterance:
"My claims upon the dwarf are already bestowed

speaker: Sir Lancelot du Lac

utterance:
"And you, fair maid? Will you return him to his

speaker: King Arthur

"Oh, yes. I did not want him, any way," began

utterance:
"My poor gifts seem unfortunate to-day, but it is as

utterance:
"There he is!" cried she joyfully,

utterance:
"It seems to me, young mistress, that you have

"They have been very kind to me; and Sir Per-

"No, ma'am, except being very kind to me; and I

utterance: Do you see that, Lady Ermengarde?

utterance: A mantle and a drinking horn, fair king. utterance: And what, that either knight or lady can offer, will repay you for such rich and curious gifts, fair son?

speaker: Dame Guinevere

utterance: At your majesty's command.

utterance: Here, boy, give it me in mine own hands, and let me see if I can not wear it without such mis- chance.

utterance: Lady, that fire was but a sign Of fires that hotter, fiercer burn; They do not come from me or mine, But shall be yours, unless you turn.

speaker: Sir Craddocke

utterance: See! Here is one true dame, if no more—

utterance: It is the falsehood I passed upon my father and mother, when I stole away from them and home to marry you, Sir Craddocke.

utterance: Who cheats her father and her mother, Even for true love's sake, May cheat her lover for another, And holiest vows may break.

utterance: Dear little Rose, you will not refuse to allow me to put the mantle about you; for surely one so young, and wearing such a look of truth and purity, can have done no wrong.

utterance: Oh, no, they were but childish errors, and are past.

utterance: Here is what shall show, O king, the true courage and temper of these your knights and courtiers; for never coward or traitor can drink from it, let him try his best.

utterance: I drink to my king and to his queen.

utterance: My Lancelot a traitor!

utterance: Nay, boy, now thou dost indeed exceed thy license; and well can we all see that thou art but a juggling rascal. Lancelot du Lac coward or traitor! addressee: the boy and Sir Lancelot du Lac

utterance: The spell is broken, knights and gentlemen; and any now may use the drinking-horn, so that he does not let its owner meddle with it.

utterance: Our lord the king is leal and true, As who shall dare to doubt ? If there's one like him 'mong you, The horn will soon find out.

utterance: Away with this folly! My knights need no magic to prove them brave and true. Return the cup to the boy; and hark, the heralds summon us to the lists. My queen, will you break up the banquet?

utterance: Come, Rhoda, jump in, and don't dawdle.

utterance: But the tournament!-but Sir Percivale, and Sir Lancelot, and the prizes; and I am the Queen of Love and Beauty, and am to give them away!

utterance: I have to go in here to order a quantity of glasses for his Majesty of Lilliput.

utterance: After that I will take you round by the cloud-palaces, and so to the Moonglade beach, where you will find your boat. Do you want to come in, Rhoda?
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: Yes, if you please, ma'am ; but what sort of a place is it?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: No, it isn't as romantic, but it's more to the purpose, I assure you. This is my spectacle factory. Come along.
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: I shouldn't think you would need spectacles, ma'am.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Why not?
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: I thought fairies could do all they wanted to, and see and hear everything ever so far off, and-
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: All true my dear, and I do not need the spectacles for myself. I manufacture them for the market.
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: Oh! do you, ma'am?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Yes, I sell a great many spectacles, both here, and down below in your world. Our principal trade, however, is with Lilliput. The glasses magnify, you see, and the Lilliputians, when they get them on, feel themselves equal to anybody. They also have the faculty of making everything seen through them look just as the person looking wishes to see it. We sell great numbers to fond mammas, who look at their children through them; also to aged husbands of young wives; also to foolish wives of wicked husbands; and as for lovers, both male and female, they always provide themselves with fairy spectacles before they buy the engagement ring.
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: But how do all these people find you out, and how do they pay you for the spectacles?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: They don't find me out; they don't even know when they buy their glasses. I see that they need them, and I just fit. on a pair and take my pay, without the other party being a bit the wiser.
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: But what pay?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Well, it varies; but it is mostly in common sense. We fairies need a great deal of sense to manage all the affairs we have to handle; and the sorts of people I have mentioned don't seem to have any use at all for it; so I just take the sense they don't use, and give them fairy spectacles instead; so both parties are suited, don't you see?
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: And how do the Lilliputians pay you? In sense, too?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: No, in babies.
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: In-babies!
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Yes, we bring them up for fairies. We used to get them from the world, but now that the Shakers have taken to the same business, the supply runs short; so we buy Lilliput babies, and pay in spectacles. But there, I can't stop to talk any longer; stand just where you are until I come back.
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: You have them all noted down?
speaker: AN OLD CUSTOMER

utterance: Yes, madam, everything.
speaker: the master gnome

utterance: And don't forget the green ones for those jealous husbands and wives. Poor wretches, they have paid all their peace and comfort for them, and we mustn't disappoint thein of their bargain.
speaker: AN OLD CUSTOMER

utterance: Yes, madain.
speaker: the master gnome

utterance: Could you let me have a pair, ma'am?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: A pair of my spectacles, do you mean?
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: Yes, ma'am.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Why, bless you child, you have worn them all your life. How else could you have seen the Chimney-Elf and his companions, and how could you have found the way to the moon, or even so much as seen me?
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: Was it all fairy spectacles, then?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Every bit of it. You have worn them nearly all your life, and I have fitted you with about five pair, of different sizes and qualities.
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: And what have I given for them?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance:
Not much that was worth keeping, my dear. Only a little of your childish gayety, and content with common things, and a good deal of time and some little health. I believe that is about all.
I am sure the spectacles have more than paid you. But it is about time for you to get some new ones. What do you say to a pair that will make the Widow Merriam, whom your father is to marry, look like a mother to you; and show you your sister Susy's lover, Jonas Merton, in a pleasanter light than you have seen him yet; and make your own home seem like a palace, or something better than a palace to you, and—
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance: Oh, yes, yes, fairy godmother! Those are the spectacles I want! Can you give them to me, and what can I give you instead?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: They will cost you some of your self-will, some selfishness, some pride, and a good deal of trouble, my dear. But I really think it will be an excellent bargain for you; and I have already fitted the glasses to your little nose, and will take my pay when I want it.
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance:
No, you can't feel them!
Nobody knows whether they wear fairy spectacles or not; and it is one of the best jokes I know, to hear people praise their own clear-sightedness, and boast how far into a mill-stone it will carry them, when all the time, bless you, it is nothing but my glasses.
speaker: the fairy godmother

utterance:
WEL
ELL, Rhoda, are you going to keep me waiting much longer, I should like to know?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Why! where is the fairy godmother, and the chariot, and the griffins?
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Gone long ago, leaving you in such a stupid maze that you never knew when you got out, nor when I pulled down the dory, nor anything else. But here we are at one end of the moonglade, with home at the other. What do you say to starting?
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Home! It seems so queer to think of home. And then it is so many years since I went away that they will have quite forgotten me. I don't believe I want to go home, Chimney-Elf.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: So many years! Well, well! Step into the boat, and when we reach home, if they do not know you, or if you do not want to stay, I will bring you back to the moon, and you may live here forever.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Get out, and go up to the house; your father has come home, and is asking for you.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: What! are we really at home, and is father here still!
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Why, little girl, where have you been roaming? It is three or four hours since I first missed you, and it is growing late for little people to be about. When we have Mrs. Merriam here to look after things, she won't let you go on in this way.
speaker: Rhoda's father

utterance: I have been out in the dory, father, but I am going right in, and to bed, now.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: I am afraid I shan't like it then so well as I do now; but I will always try to look at the Widow Merriam through my fairy glasses. I wish I could be sure of always having them on.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: They will always be on when you wish for them, and, after a while, even without your wishing.
speaker: the Chimney-Elf

utterance: Come, child! Don't stand dream- ing there; I want to shut the door. There, go right to bed, and to sleep. Good-night?
speaker: Rhoda's father

utterance: Good-night, father dear.
speaker: Rhoda

utterance: Ah! there is no place like home, after all!
speaker: the Chimney-Elf
